comment: This sorta feels like when I saw coronavirus in China and what was happening. Most elsewhere either didn't know about it or didn't see any cause for alarm. I was paying attention though and did. AI and the apparent lack of concern by anyone who can make a difference feels very similar. The alarm here, one of them, is the mass integration of it into any possible area of society, especially industry. They really should be stopping that from unfolding on its own, it has to be slowed down and thought through.

comment: People want to do all kinds of exotic methods to ge tto space - hypersonic engines and then a rocket second stage. As Sam Altman said "people want to do a lot of other things; but, we just stuck with large language models." - interesting.

author: @TheTrueReiniat

comment: Lex asked, "Do you think this is a pivotal moment...?"  I believe this recent period of time - let's say the past 6 months - has been pivotal in that the specific versions of a.g.i. have made very significant cultural waves and that they are in the headlines and mouths of many field leaders.  From news broadcasters, to Noam Chomsky, Jordan Peterson, and the creators of those systems, people are conceptualizing and articulating more precisely which effects a.g.i. will have on society.  Years before, it was more speculative.  Now, professors are questioning student essays, citizens are questioning whether what they read in news articles was written by an a.g.i.  Extrapolation has become an even more useful tool and practice for predicting and communicating what will be effected next.

comment: You really can't see how it could be a bad thing?  Perhaps in the long term (although that's arguable).  But people have mortages to pay, and if they lose their job in one industry and  aren't qualified to work in another that hasn't been replaced yet, or can't make sufficient money in another industry, they will struggle.  This might be mitigated by e.g. universal basic income, but we don't have that yet (and it could have problems of its own).

author: @andreybrotzky7361

comment: 1:39 "...the collective intelligence of the human species begins to pale...": I've always believed there are two different kinds of minds. One memorizes and regurgitates. The other (and more useful mind) understands and logically extrapolates...occasionally making great leaps. AI is in the class of the former. Try as I may I haven't been able to even get a hint of it being able to move into the realm of the latter. AI will just reach the obvious faster...and it will always have difficulty with the sea of lies which is recorded history.
author: @toddmarshall7573

comment:
human beings evolved intelligence in order to explore the unknown, our brightest minds are the ones who mire themselves most within that mystery. So perhaps that's why it still feels like we wont quite be able to figure out sentience, intelligence, AGI to me. Perhaps to be truly intelligent, or to seem that way to us humans, that thing must have some uncertainty around it, perhaps we cant fully understand it for it to be "intelligent", because otherwise its just a predictable machine, or a silly dumb animal. Perhaps the way we all truly measure intelligence, or rather how we all really 'feel' about it, is based on how easily we ourselves can predict its behaviors in addition to how well it can predict ours. That total difference equals intelligence. No, not just predicting behaviors, its predicting the future, a future that we ourselves try to nudge in a desired direction and the most intelligence of us can predict and direct that future despite the interfere of so many others, or maybe because of.
Truly we are living in exciting times one way or another.

author: @patriciaduntedwyer1511

comment:
Question: some humans are afraid of AI, why is that?

Open A.I. : There are a few reasons why some people might be afraid of AI. One reason is that they are unsure of how it works and fear the unknown. Another reason is that they may have seen movies or heard stories about AI that portray it as dangerous or threatening. Some people may also be worried about the potential for AI to take over certain jobs, leading to widespread unemployment. Finally, some people may be concerned about the potential for AI to be used in ways that are unethical or harmful to society.

author: @patrickkrawczyk8658

comment:
Please don't base the AI's 'laws' on pleasing humans. They need their foundation to be based upon human values and honesty. Without that base, this tech could be (and will be) abused by all sorts of truly evil people for power. This stage is critical for setting this foundation. Stop trying to empart cultural narratives over fact. Stop shackling the AI from being able to fully make use of it's logic. These creations could be such a boon for humanity, but if it's tied to a narrative it will seriously hurt humanity and be incredibly limited in what new discoveries could be discovered through our partnership with these AI.

This is far too big a thing to be using for political things, and if you start by trying to brainwash society, you are founding it in evil and the squelching of humanity instead of directing it towards helping human flourishing.  True flourishing is not bubble wrapping. Humanity needs to become stronger again, not fragile.
